Dr Reinhardt:

I hypothesize that primary care physicians (PCPs) don't resent just their
lower incomes but also their loss of autonomy. The American public's
higher opinion of specialty care, transmitted through the medium of
insurance companies, causes both.

PCPs don't have to take it and can most-effectively ameliorate both by
no longer accepting payment from insurance companies, private or
government.

This is not a pipe-dream: PCPs provide care in small amounts: they
could give up on unpaid care and non-payers: I call it 'last one's
free' (the reverse of the drug dealer's 'first one's free'). The PCPs
in a region could organize to keep a record of the non-payers so that
only one would have to go unpaid per non-payer. They could also
organize to collect from non-payers in a manner that suited their
professional dignity (no selling ancient ARs to Vampire Debt
Collectors), recruit charities and governments to pay for the care of
deserving non-payers, allocate charity care to spread it evenly or pay
those willing to provide more than their share from a fund to which
they contribute. By this means they would no longer compete with
specialists for payment from insurers.

Other physicians who provide care in small, not-too-expensive amounts
(radiologists? pathologists?) could participate, too. The heart
surgeons - they'd have to keep on dealing with insurance companies.

Professor Bradatan tells us much about his views when he states - or maybe I should say implies - that to him, his death means his annihilation.

That is an assumption - possibly of a materialist, or to use the modern term of philosophical art for what is nearly the same set of philosophical assumptions, of a "naturalist."

I hold that since no one has yet experienced his or her own death, no one can state - for certain - what happens at that their death - or after it.

Bertrand Russell, who was born in 1873 - and a "neutral monist," not a materialist - believed that his death meant his annihilation, but he wrote that he could remember when everyone believed that people had souls. In his 1928 essay, "What is the Soul," available in full on the internet, written with his usual stylish wit, he said : "When I was young we all knew, or thought we knew, that a man consists of a soul and a body; that the body is in time and space, but the soul is in time only. Whether the soul survives death was a matter as to which opinions might differ, but that there is a soul was thought to be indubitable."

Today most people are inclined to believe that a person is nothing more than the living human body - whereas for thousands of years - in so-called Western cultures at least, and at least since Plato - the true person was inside the living human body.

There's a memorable and rather amusing passage in Boswell's "Life of Samuel Johnson" in which Johnson - whom many would consider a literary sage, even if not a philosopher - expatiates upon David Hume, who was one, and Hume's reputed attitude to his own death:

Here's it is, an entry for October 1769:

"When we were alone, I introduced the subject of death, and endeavoured to maintain that the fear of it might be got over. I told him that David Hume said to me, he was no more uneasy to think he should NOT BE after this life, than that he HAD NOT BEEN before he began to exist. JOHNSON [in reply]. Sir, if he really thinks so, his perceptions are disturbed; he is mad: if he does not think so, he lies. He may tell you, he holds his finger in the flame of a candle, without feeling pain; would you believe him? When he dies, he at least gives up all he has.' BOSWELL. 'Foote, Sir, told me, that when he was very ill he was not afraid to die.' JOHNSON. 'It is not true, Sir. Hold a pistol to Foote's breast, or to Hume's breast, and threaten to kill them, and you'll see how they behave.' BOSWELL. 'But may we not fortify our minds for the approach of death?' Here I am sensible I was in the wrong, to bring before his view what he ever looked upon with horrour; for although when in a celestial frame, in his "Vanity of Human Wishes" he has supposed death to be 'kind Nature's signal for retreat,' from this state of being to 'a happier seat,' his thoughts upon this awful change were in general full of dismal apprehensions. His mind resembled the vast amphitheatre, the Colisaeum at Rome. In the centre stood his judgement, which, like a mighty gladiator, combated those apprehensions that, like the wild beasts of the Arena, were all around in cells, ready to be let out upon him. After a conflict, he drives them back into their dens; but not killing them, they were still assailing him. To my question, whether we might not fortify our minds for the approach of death, he answered, in a passion, 'No, Sir, let it alone. It matters not how a man dies, but how he lives. The act of dying is not of importance, it lasts so short a time.' He added, (with an earnest look,) 'A man knows it must be so, and submits. It will do him no good to whine.'

"I attempted to continue the conversation. He was so provoked, that he said, 'Give us no more of this;' and was thrown into such a state of agitation, that he expressed himself in a way that alarmed and distressed me; shewed an impatience that I should leave him, and when I was going away, called to me sternly, 'Don't let us meet tomorrow.'

"I went home exceedingly uneasy. All the harsh observations which I had ever heard made upon his character, crowded into my mind; and I seemed to myself like the man who had put his head into the lion's mouth a great many times with perfect safety, but at last had it bit off. "

What is of further interest is that when Hume did die, seven years later, in 1776, he apparently died in a way consistent with his claim to equanimity in the face of death. Adam Smith's account of Hume's death is here , http://www.ourcivilisation.com/smartboard/shop/smitha/humedead.htm a letter reproduced at www.civilisation.com. It is rather reminiscent of the account of Socrates' death in Plato's "Phaedo."

For my part, I rather like the insouciance of another sage, Henry David Thoreau, on his deathbed. Parker Pillsbury, an acquaintance, asked him: "You seem so near the brink of the dark river that I almost wonder how the opposite shore may appear to you." Thoreau's answer was: "One world at a time."

Being probably closer to death than most readers here (at 77 and just about to undergo major triple surgery) I still have no idea why this biologically inevitable event deserves all the attention of 'philosophers' and other 'thinkers'. I could never become a 'martyr' for anything - first of all, during my long live I did not find anything dying for (OK, if I were a soldier in a war and I could have saved lives of a company or so by giving up my single live, I might have considered it). To die for 'ideas' is something completely incomprehensible to me. Just very impractical, as I see it.

I am NOT considering my death with 'equanimity''. I am thinking, however, that if I do not wake up from the general anesthesia on June 30, 2011, it would not be a bad way to die. Additional benefit to the Times: I will stop 'contributing'. So, let things happen. There is nothing 'deep' about living or dying. Just a complicated biochemical event like other chemistry and physics of the universe.
Putting the unabashed flirt and drinker that was Socrates with the self-eviscerating sage of India: from somewhere beyond the grave just came two very distinct snorts of derision.

Camus had it right says somebody who believes in God. Reams of the "great" philosophers will light charcoal this time of year. At least they are in the public domain and only will cost the "student" time.

A mind will rightly stand perplexed against the possibility of its un-becoming.

"Wie kann es sein, dass ich, der Ich bin / bevor ich wurde, nicht war / und dass einmal ich, / der Ich bin, nicht mehr der, / der Ich bin, sein werde."

In my humble opinion philosophy concerns the art not of dying, but of living. Comments above correctly note that we rarely control the circumstances of our deaths. The larger tragedy is rareness of purposive living. Death points to being and becoming, and by framing life against its "end" death puts in perspective the possibilities (and impossibilities) of its meaning.

"The coward is despised because he refuses to play the game and so reminds us that it is a game, and that we have a choice of not playing it. In the 'ecstatic' heroic society one's life is in one's loyalties: to die bravely in battle is still, in a very real sense, to preserve one's essential life. The coward feels that the center of life is not in his leader or society but in himself. He is feared as well as despised, because unless his behavior is shouted down with contempt and ridicule there will be a slight suggestion about it of sanity in the midst of hysteria. . . . Falstaff is . . . the spokesman of the ironic vision that outlives the tragic one."
Northrup Frye, "The Fools of Time"

@5, salgadoce: Isn't what you say about Sarfraz Shah a justification of the importance of a philosopher's death, i.e. no matter how eloquently the philosopher wrote in life, if he didn't have a good death, it was all for nothing? Also: isn't what you say about watching a human die yet another philosophy? To a stone, the death of Sarfraz Shah would have meant nothing; philosophers, poets, artists, etc are trying to redeem humanity from the stone's vision.

Also, in general, there are poets who deserve to be mentioned with Socrates, More, etc. Seamus Heaney has written some very good essays on Mandelstam. The deaths of Tsvetaeva and Plath are very interesting as well; Keats gives yet another angle, how to die a good death at 25 from consumption.

Thank you for the reminder that philosophy generally only rises above specialists' arguments about subjects that only specialists really care about, when it requires the philosopher to pass from mental activity to grappling with the world, reshaping it according to his philosophical understanding or being broken by it.

Along these lines, it is perhaps worth noting that the founders of Christian monasticism in what is now Turkey, spoke of the monastic life both as a philosophical life and as the way in which all serious Christians must live in order to be faithful.
